item.title: New Year’s Eve Specials, Plus 4 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: CNN, CBS and ABC ring in 2026, and a new reality show set in Palm Beach begins.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez

media:content.media:credit: Adrienne Grunwald for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: From left: Andy Cohen and Anderson Cooper during the 2024 CNN New Year’s Eve special.

item.title: Cómo el petróleo, las drogas y la inmigración impulsaron la campaña de EE. UU. contra Venezuela
item.description: Nuevos detalles revelan cómo agendas cruzadas dentro del gobierno de Trump condujeron a una confrontación cada vez más militarizada.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Tyler Pager, Charlie Savage, Julian E. Barnes and Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El secretario de Estado Marco Rubio, a la izquierda, y el secretario de Defensa Pete Hegseth, a la derecha, han sido actores clave, junto con el asesor presidencial Stephen Miller, en la escalada del conflicto del presidente Trump contra Venezuela.

item.title: Why We Keep Falling for Narcissistic Leaders
item.description: We should know better.
item.dc:creator: Adam Grant

media:content.media:credit: Tim Enthoven

item.title: China Will Hold Live-Fire Military Exercises Around Taiwan
item.description: The exercises end months of relative calm across the Taiwan Strait and come after the Trump administration announced arms sales to the island.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien

media:content.media:credit: Tsai Hsin-Han/Reuters
media:content.media:description: A news report on China’s “Justice Mission 2025” military drills appears on a television at a noodle shop in Taipei, Taiwan, on Monday.

item.title: The World Wants More Ube. Philippine Farmers Are Struggling to Keep Up.
item.description: Soaring demand and extreme weather worsened by climate change have wiped out harvests of the popular purple yam.
item.dc:creator: Rambo Talabong and Jes Aznar

item.title: No Corrections: Dec. 29, 2025
item.description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 29, 2025.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Brigitte Bardot, 91, French Actress Who Renounced Stardom, Dies
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 29, 2025.
Processing the purple yam at the Food Processing Center at Benguet State University.

item.title: With Critical Decisions Ahead, Netanyahu Faces Mounting Pressure
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has a series of vexing choices to make in the year ahead on issues including Gaza, conscription and a judicial overhaul, with elections looming.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger

media:content.media:credit: Nathan Howard for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in Jerusalem in October.

item.description: A farmer harvesting purple yams from the side of the mountain this month in Benguet Province in the Philippines.

item.title: Trump Says the U.S. Struck a ‘Big Facility’ in Campaign Against Venezuela
item.description: The administration provided no details of what the president said was an attack last week linked to U.S. efforts to disrupt drug trafficking from Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Such an attack would be the first on land since President Trump began his military campaign against Venezuela.

item.title: Mexico Train Derailment Kills 13 People
item.description: The train was carrying around 250 passengers and crew members on a cross-country route linking the Pacific and the Gulf of Mexico. Nearly 100 people were injured.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal

media:content.media:credit: Rusvel Rasgado/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Mexican emergency workers rescuing passengers from a train that derailed in the southern state of Oaxaca on Sunday.

item.title: Readers Share Eco-Friendly Projects Happening In Their Communities
item.description: Readers submitted more than 3,200 ideas for our 50 States, 50 Fixes series. Before the year ends, we wanted to share just a few more of them.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Catrin Einhorn

item.title: Suspect Confessed to Planting Pipe Bombs Near the Capitol Before Jan. 6
item.description: A Virginia man was charged with planting the bombs outside Democratic and Republican headquarters. Court documents show he believed that the 2020 election had been “tampered with.”
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

media:content.media:credit: F.B.I., via Reuters
media:content.media:description: Surveillance footage in January 2021 showed the man authorities identified as Brian Cole Jr. He told investigators he felt relieved that the bombs had not exploded and that no one was hurt.

item.title: Don Bryant, 83, Dies; Co-Wrote ‘I Can’t Stand the Rain’ for His Wife
item.description: He and Ann Peebles made up one of Southern soul’s most accomplished partnerships. He finally broke through as a solo act at 75.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub

media:content.media:credit: David Wolff-Patrick/Redferns, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Don Bryant in 2018 onstage with the Bo-Keys in Paris. “I guess it’s my time at last,” he said of his comeback as a performer late in life.

item.title: Trump and Zelensky Meet to Iron Out Peace Plan, but Deal Remains Elusive
item.description: The U.S. president said after a meeting at Mar-a-Lago that a deal was “maybe very close.” But a joint U.S.-Ukraine proposal appeared unfinished, as Russia rejected several ideas.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi and Katie Rogers

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump hosted President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine at Mar-a-Lago on Sunday. “In a few weeks, we’ll know one way or another,” Mr. Trump said of a peace deal.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Dec. 29, 2025
item.description: Chase Dittrich brings us a first-class puzzle.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

media:content.media:credit: Cheryl Senter for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: When it comes to crossword trivia, don’t let anyone tell you not to look up.

item.title: Five Brigitte Bardot Movies to Stream
item.description: The actress, who died at 91, had what can’t be taught: charisma and attitude onscreen. Here are some highlights.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

item.title: Winter Storm Batters Minnesota, Bringing ‘Potentially Life-Threatening Travel Conditions’
item.description: Forecasters warned that whiteouts had reduced visibility in Minnesota. More heavy snow was expected in the region through Monday.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz

media:content.media:credit: Jerry Holt/Star Tribune, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Heavy snow on Sunday in Minneapolis, part of a system that disrupted air travel and made driving hazardous.

item.title: The Best of Culture
item.description: Our culture and lifestyle editor looks back at the year’s top pop culture moments.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: ¿Cuál es el papel de Colombia en el narcotráfico mundial?
item.description: El presidente Gustavo Petro está enzarzado en una guerra de palabras con el presidente Donald Trump sobre el papel de Colombia en el tráfico mundial de drogas. El asunto es complicado.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: Ramón Campos Iriarte for The New York Times

item.title: T Magazine’s Essential 2025 Travel Guides
item.description: Recommendations for where to go and how to get there, from the ultimate Japan itinerary to the best small cruise ships.
item.dc:creator: T Magazine

item.title: Muere Brigitte Bardot, estrella de cine francés, a los 91 años
item.description: En la década de 1950, “Y Dios creó a la mujer” la convirtió en un símbolo sexual mundialmente conocido. Más tarde abandonó la actuación para dedicar su vida a la protección de los animales.
item.dc:creator: Anita Gates

media:content.media:credit: Robert Walker/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Brigitte Bardot en 1965, en la cima de su estrellato cinematográfico. Estaba en el Hotel Plaza de Nueva York promocionando la comedia wéstern ¡Viva María!, por la que recibió su única nominación a un premio de actuación, en el Reino Unido.

item.title: 15-Year-Old Is Fatally Shot in Stairwell of Bronx Building
item.description: A 14-year-old boy was also wounded in the shooting, which happened at a New York City Housing Authority building. The police said they were looking for six people involved in the violence.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius and Miles G. Cohen

media:content.media:credit: Dakota Santiago for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Officers from the 49th Precinct responded to a shooting in the Eastchester Gardens houses in the Bronx on Saturday.

item.title: Pilot Is Dead After Helicopters Crash in New Jersey
item.description: Another pilot was in critical condition, according to the fire chief in Hammonton, N.J., where the crash took place.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri

media:content.media:credit: WPVI-TV/6ABC, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: The two helicopters both plunged to the ground after the midair collision.

item.title: Vienna’s Ball Season Traditions of Waltzes and White Ties
item.description: The annual Vienna Philharmonic Ball anchors a winter calendar of some 450 dances across the city that open a window into Viennese tradition, then and now.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Schmid

item.title: A Star Conductor Brings Sparkle to Vienna’s New Year’s Concert
item.description: For the first time, Yannick Nézet-Séguin will lead the Vienna Philharmonic’s most-watched event of the year: its annual concert on New Year’s Day.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri

media:content.media:credit: Rob Cardillo for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Yannick Nézet-Séguin is the music director of the Metropolitan Opera and the Philadelphia Orchestra, and artistic director of the Orchestre Métropolitain in Montreal.

item.title: Vienna to Stage Gender-Bending, Jazz Age Comedy Once Banned by Franco
item.description: MusikTheater an der Wien will stage Pablo Luna’s “Benamor,” a rarely seen example of the Spanish zarzuela genre from the Roaring Twenties in Madrid.
item.dc:creator: David Belcher

media:content.media:credit: Florentina Olareanu for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: David Oller left, as Juan de León, and Federico Fiorio as Darío in “Benamor,” which will be performed at the MusikTheater an der Wien starting next month.

item.title: Gmail to Let Users Change Their Addresses While Keeping Data
item.description: Under the shift, which Google said would eventually be rolled out to all users, old addresses would remain active. Messages and services would not be lost.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan

media:content.media:credit: Dado Ruvic/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Google has quietly started to roll out a way for users to change their Gmail addresses ending with @gmail.com, and keep all their emails.

item.title: Syrian Protests Over Lack of Security Leave 2 Dead
item.description: Days after a bombing at a mosque in a predominantly Alawite area, members of the religious minority in Syria demonstrated for better protections.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

media:content.media:credit: Karam Al-Masri/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Members of the Syrian security forces standing guard during a protest by people from the Alawite religious minority in Latakia, Syria, on Sunday.

item.title: Man Charged in Fatal Shooting During Backyard Target Practice
item.description: The Oklahoma man had bought himself a Glock .45 handgun for Christmas and was shooting at an energy drink can when a woman nearby was fatally struck, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

media:content.media:credit: Google Maps
media:content.media:description: Sandra Phelps was fatally shot while sitting on a covered porch with two adult family members and two children.

item.title: Quick Mushroom Stroganoff Recipe
item.description: I’m too exhausted to pull off anything big, but I still crave a meal that feels like a holiday. Enter Hetty Lui McKinnon’s 30-minute vegetarian wonder.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Ko

media:content.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.
media:content.media:description: Hetty Lui McKinnon’s mushroom stroganoff.

item.title: Brigitte Bardot: A Life in Pictures
item.description: The movies made the French actress a star, but photography sealed her stardom.

item.title: Behold the ‘God of Generous Out-Flowing Love’: A Q&A With N.T. Wright

media:content.media:credit: Andrea Solario, via Metropolitan Museum of Art

item.title: The Democratic Party Avoids a Reckoning
item.description: Readers fault Democrats for stalling a report on their 2024 failures. Also: A lawyer’s faith in freedom; a rabbi responds to JD Vance’s claim of a Christian nation.

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Over the summer, those briefed on the D.N.C.’s planned report said it planned to skirt the question of whether former President Joseph R. Biden Jr. should have run for re-election, as well as key decisions from former Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign.

item.title: Make-Ahead Breakfast Ideas
item.description: The host of our Cooking newsletter offers a few suggestions for New Year’s Day breakfasts.

media:content.media:description: French toast casserole.

item.title: Forget Willpower. If You Want to Resist Temptation, You’ll Need Something Else.
item.description: Rather than try to resist temptation in the moment, many successful people arrange their lives to minimize the need for willpower in the first place.

item.title: A Book Is Never Finished With Us
item.description: Consider that every book you have is a story of who you are.
item.dc:creator: Roger Rosenblatt

item.title: When A.I. Took My Job, I Bought a Chain Saw
item.description: I was now facing the same reality my working-class neighbors knew well: the world had changed, my work had all but disappeared, and still, the bills wouldn’t stop coming.
item.dc:creator: Brian Groh

item.title: From Sex Appeal to the Far Right, Brigitte Bardot Symbolized a Changing France
item.description: In the decades after becoming a megastar, the French actress became as known for her politics as she once had been for her acting career.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

media:content.media:credit: Herbert Dorfman/Corbis, via Getty Images

item.title: Brigitte Bardot, French Movie Icon Who Renounced Stardom, Dies at 91
item.description: “And God Created Woman” made her a world-famous sex symbol in the 1950s. She later gave up acting to devote her life to animal welfare.
item.dc:creator: Anita Gates

media:content.media:credit: Robert Walker/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Brigitte Bardot in 1965, when she was at the height of her movie stardom. She was at the Plaza Hotel in New York promoting the western comedy “Viva Maria!” for which she received her only acting-award nomination, in Britain.

item.title: Zelensky to Meet With Trump at Mar-a-Lago About Plan to End War With Russia
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine brings a revised 20-point peace proposal, as well as doubts about whether Russia is serious about pursuing peace.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times & Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: ¿Hemos subestimado a Kate Hudson?
item.description: Por años, los estudios han empujado a Hudson a la senda de las comedias románticas. Su papel como una madre trabajadora enamorada de Neil Diamond podría llevarla de nuevo a los Oscar.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes and Thea Traff

item.title: En 2025, el k-pop luchó contra sus demonios
item.description: El género alcanzó su punto álgido en términos de fama mundial con ‘Las guerreras k-pop’, mientras que el nuevo grupo más prometedor de la industria estuvo sumido en un marasmo legal.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica

media:content.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Danielle de NewJeans en el escenario en Hong Kong en marzo. El grupo esperaba arrancar una era distinta con un nuevo comienzo, pero sigue con su antiguo contrato discográfico.
